awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Engineering a Community-Family Partnership: Developing a Program Aimed at Making and Design Practices in Home Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Families play a vital role in children's paths toward STEM careers yet little is knowns about how this influence works. This project addresses this knowledge gap by developing, implementing, and refining a program for integrating Making and engineering design practices into the home environments of families from under-resourced communities. The researchers hypothesize that an intervention focused on engaging underserved youth and their caregivers about ways to implement Making/engineering design practices in their home will enhance their awareness of and affinity for STEM careers relative to those who do not participate. The project has 3 specific aims. (1) Investigate features of the intervention that best support participation and implementation of Making/engineering design practices in home environments.  (2) Investigate changes in each youth's STEM identity in relation to engaging in Making/engineering design practices with caregivers in their home.  (3) Examine shifts in parental: (a) views of engineering, (b) support for their child's engagement in engineering design practices, and (c) beliefs about engineering as a viable degree/career option for their child.
 
The project is unique in that it takes a rare process look at how students and families engage in home-based STEM activities. It concurrently assesses families' readiness to support STEM career awareness and children's engagement in home-based STEM activities. The target audience is families with children in grades 3-6 enrolled in Title I schools in Bloomington, Indiana and Broome County, New York. Project partners include the Boys and Girls Clubs in these communities who assist with recruitment and with the delivery of the intervention, Family Making Nights. At home, families will document their design activities as they unfold. Stimulated recall with video and semi-structured interviews will help the research team understand families' thinking about what occurred during the activities. The use of a comparison group allows the team to compare the behaviors and outcomes associated with "trained" and "untrained" family supports. Grounded in social cognitive career theory and research on interest, the project's focus on identity development has potential to inform theories of social learning. As such, the project will advance the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program's efforts to better understand and promote practices that increase student motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was a collaboration between Indiana University - Bloomington and Binghamton University. As a research team, our long-term goal is to increase the number of individuals from traditionally marginalized groups who are aware of and may enter and persist in pathways to STEM careers. This project was our attempt at an alternative approach to address this goal - inclusion of caregivers as critical members in this process. We sought to develop a program for families with children in grades 3-6 to engage in activities that mimic the engineering design process, but doing so within the context of the home, school or community. Through this project, we developed 12 engineering-focused kits and a facilitation guide that highlights the ins and outs of the program (e.g., recruitment approaches, communication with parents) and provides additional resources (e.g., online show-and-tell games). These can be accessed at https://athomeengineers.com/. We created our engineering kits using the following five design principles: (1) leverage familiar environments and materials such as cardboard boxes, cotton balls, and yarn; (2) broaden the understanding of engineers and the process of engineering; (3) support the development of knowledge and skills of both adults and children through activities that have multiple approaches; (4) balance - frustration/failure with iteration and creativity with procedures; and (5) position caregivers as engineering facilitators and co-learners. We are expanding our work to develop kits for families with a child in pre-kindergarten to grade 1 and for homeschool families due to the positive outcomes from this project.

Impact on Children

For the children in our project, our research showed the multiple ways they positively developed their identities as engineers. For example, many children expressed how their actions and behaviors were similar to those used by practicing engineers. The most common way they expressed doing engineering was through their experiences with failures (when things don't work out). Throughout the program, children became more comfortable with failures and were able to develop creative ways to overcome challenges. Furthermore, this project increased the interest in engineering for some children. As stated by Annie, a sixth-grade child, "I could see myself being an engineer and designing things that would help people or something." Lastly, children were afforded the opportunity to engage in mathematics and science concepts and practices through the engineering kits.

Impact on Caregivers

Our results also showed that caregivers play a unique role as educators because they know the prior experiences of their child(ren) (e.g., trip to local science center), family history, frustration points, and fine motor skills. Caregivers shared how the program shifted their interactions with their child(ren),including being more detailed and understandable when explaining how things work, reconsidering the types of questions asked, and asking their child(ren) for help when repairing something. Some parents even positioned their children as partners, or even lead engineers, in solving problems and challenges together.

In this project, caregivers were able to support their children as engineers, but also facilitate and discuss math and science concepts with their child(ren) within the completion of the engineering kits. As one example, caregivers acknowledged the frustrations of their children during failure moments, and chose to model how to work through it or suggest ways to move beyond frustrations and failures. We also observed caregivers teaching their child(ren) everyday concepts and ideas such as why there are so many stray animals in the U.S. or why we do not get near water during a lightening storm.

Through the project, caregivers gained new insights into the developpment of their child(ren), with many describing how their child(ren) developed new processes and modeled the thinking and perseverance of engineers. Caregiers also noted the development of an inquisitive mindset regarding how their child(ren) used and transformed materials and objects in their home and community environments.

Conclusion

Despite challenges created by COVID-19 that made it hard for us to work directly with families, we were able to create scenarios that allowed families an opportunity to work together to explore engineering - a field that is less prevalent in school settings. We thing the variation in the types of kits (i.e., content and level of challenge) along with the flexibility in when, where, and how families engaged with the kits increased the success of the project. Broadly, the collective results from this project point to the home environment as a site to potentially diminish exclusionary and inequitable access to out-of-school learning environments, including travel, cost and seeing STEM as unapproachable. Further, the engagement of children in the program has the potential to increase their likelihood of entering and persisting in pathways to STEM careers.
